text:
I have just purchased one of these machines and I can't get the laser beam in the tube to show or switch on. Water flow using supplied pump and distilled water are fine, although the rubber tubing supplied is crap and folds readily, with a series of clothes pegs, I have been able to press it open along full length providing no restriction to water flow. Power switches on and off to the machine okay, emergency stop working fine, temperature LCDs and Power LED working fine, as are the adjustment buttons. No damage to the box it came in or obvious damage inside, laser tube is watertight ie no cracks visible and no leakage. Set laser power to 30% following instructions in the instruction manual for mirror alignment on mirror 1, set masking tape across mirror  1 and pressed the pulse button. Result - no laser beam, and no burn on the centre of masking tape. Tried beam switched on constant, still no purple laser beam in the tube (as appears at time point 1.20 on the video) or burn on paper. I have tried increasing and decreasing power and temperatures in the tube have remained about 28 degrees C.
My machine does not appear to have a flow switch, having pulled the tubes both ways in the casing to their full possible extent. Is there anything else I need to do or can try other than sending it back to the supplier for a refund?
video: Is a 40W CO2 Laser Cutter Worth?  OM Tech K40 Revi

text:
I didnt hear much about the speed of the glow forge in your review.  Personally, I think it is painfully slow. when I first started looking for a laser, I saw reviews just like this, and got all fired up and excited.  however, after digging deeper, checking out the specs, comparing this to others on the market, and then factoring in the total lack of actual support ( other than the community forums ), having to return the unit to even replace a tube, and for almost every other things, at. great cost - I soon realised, this was actually not a great machine for the money they are demanding for it.  It looks very nice, but, it just doesn't command the price.  

they do an excellent job of marketing, an immense job, but they they would ( in my opinion ) provide a much better product, with support if they pent less on the advertising and more into the product itself.  Once I made an initial enquiry, I was almost hounded by e-mail after e-mail after e-mail.  however when I replied with questions, their answers were always very vague, or often they would deviate from my question, paying lip service to it only, and trying to big up everything else in an attempt to negate my concerns, and convince me that despite my concern, there were so many other aspects that were simply amazing...anyway... hard pass for me im afraid

I love your reviews in general, but I do have to say, I think this one was probably biased as a result of glow forge sending you the laser and air purifier etc..I know you said it wasn't, but it did sound like it.
video: Should You Buy a Glowforge?

text: Personally after starting my laser experience with an Orturn 20w diode laser with lightburn, I'm hooked on lightburn. I personally believe it to be better all around then the software you use with the Glowforge. IF the Glowforge used lightburn, I'd save my money and buy one, but lightburn is the tool that tells me it's totally worth buying and upgrading the most expensive chinese laser you/I can afford.  50 or 60 watt IMHO !  Lightburn is just too awesome to not have available.
video: Should you upgrade a budget laser cutter?

text:
I started in March with an Ortur Laser Master 2 Diode machine to dip my toes in and see if I liked laser engraving.
Last month I had a OmTech 60w CO2 machine with 20"x28" build surface delivered (eBay).   Got Lightburn when I had the Ortur and was a simple process to upgrade the license to work with the Ruida controller on the 60w machine.  Makes for an amazingly capable machine with plenty of power for my current goals.

I don't think there's anyway I'd be satisfied with a Glowforge.  Proprietary software, internet connection required, and could become a brick any day if the company ever shut down.

Note: Ortur machine sold on Facebook Marketplace within 24 hours for about what I paid for it (of course I included all my upgrades so it was certainly more valuable than stock).
video: Should you upgrade a budget laser cutter?

text:
It really does seem that with laser engravers, you really do actually get what you pay for.
Every cost tier adds significant ease of use or completely new capabilities.
Is a IS900 from Gravotech $20,000+ yeah. However, it is twice as fast and versatile as anything this guy has, and the software is phenomenal. Buy chinesium, get chinesium. Buy kickstarter, maybe get good hobbyist machine that will run 2-10 jobs a day. Pay double, run 100s of jobs a day.

text:
Whether it is laser engraving or laser cutting, in fact, the most important thing is two points, one is the laser power and the other is the smoothness of the frame movement.
Laser power not only depends on the input voltage and current, but also depends on the good or bad laser diode, a good diode can make you more quickly into the perfect carving, on the market these products, the laser spot compression is the best, whether you are cutting or carving, despite the product is not good but have as much as possible to Advertisement and make the spot compression of the product is difficult to show the light.https://youtu.be/qAwesZPInhw

text: There is no argument that the fit and finish of the Glowforge is first rate.  But there are too many limiting factors, especially the closed ecosystem, where even if the company does not fold, you are beholden to their marketing changes.  Just ask any Cricket user of the last couple of months.  Yes, Cricket backed out of their proposed changes, but for a while, there was the potential to basically owning a brick..  Should Glowforge find itself in financial difficulties, what is to stop them from charging for functionality that already exists and is part of the package, or jacking up the cost of their subscription service, after people have integrated the glowforge into their process (if commercial).  Sadly, this is a hard pass for me.
video: Should You Buy a Glowforge?

text:
Glad you did this Glowforge review, which confirm that the Muse 3D or Muse core with your own chiller an inline fan and 45W upgrade, plus interchangeable lenses and rotary tool, still under $6k or even better the Beambox pro with a standard 50W,  integrated chiller, rotary attachment (no interchangeable lenses) still less than $6k both locally operated without internet, are better options for someone looking more for the money. 

Thanks for the review.
video: Should You Buy a Glowforge?

text:
There's no way I'd buy a piece of expensive hardware like this, that turns into a brick if/when the company folds or decides not to support it

I had that (company folded) happen to me with a 3d printer. Expensive lesson.
video: Should You Buy a Glowforge?

text: yea im not paying thousands to be limited to a website that wont be around in 5 years, with payment teirs and with, the bonus of buying material from them,I know its semi optional but still, greedy much? This entire thing reaks of a future dick move big time leaving users with a 3-5K brick
video: Should You Buy a Glowforge?

text:
The reviewed equipment adds up to basically $7000. A quick look at OMTech shows you can get 100w, 24x40 (and passthrough), autofocus, a much deeper maximum depth (tumbler engraving anyone?), an actual chiller, two different styles of rotary machines, Corel graphics suite, and Lightburn for $6360. You'll have $640 left to spend on a camera for Lightburn so you'll have the same functionality as SlowForge. You'll also have a much bigger machine with more than twice the power and the ability to fix small things like laser alignment (good luck re-aligning your shiny new Glowforge if it gets bumped during shipping). The only thing you'll be missing is the air purifier and there are plenty of cost effective options out there.

Glowforge shouldn't be compared to a cheap k40; it should be compared to what else you can get for the cost. For the cost, there are much better options.

Btw, their $3000 basic machine gets equally spanked by a 50w OMTech. They do have great advertising though and the entire laser community has benefitted from it.
video: Should You Buy a Glowforge?

text:
Personally for the cost, I would rather a 50w and lightburn, sure you will need a chiller and a bigger extractor, but the inability to be able to use a rotary, or a decent thickness of wood and the low power, the hard to clean, the fact you cant repair anything on it your self... Give me a machine I can work on my self every day of the week. 

also closed ecosysytem for software nope sorry thats where pain comes, give it a few years and when glowforge decide they don't want to support it any more tough! (See Cricut for example of this happening) 

Having a sealed path is a terrible idea in my view, replacing mirrors will be needed in the future and I bet that's a return to glow forge for them to do it and if its not then it will be an expensive option .

A few questions, 
1) How long is the laser tube? cos it doesnt look like a real 40W have they done the trick of saying its peak and using that as a selling point, it looks (to me at least) more like a 35w tube. 
2) What's the fluid used for the cooling? does it have a decent amount of fluid in it? considering the size of most chillers they are bigger than the whole machine so what is it using? 
3) What's the max cutting and engraving speed? 
4) How easy to replace the lens? and how expensive? 


My personal opinion is they are over priced and they also could do with someone understanding lasers doing the marketing (its not a printer for example) and to be honest they have a really bad reputation for going wrong due to things like ribbon cables, I guess they are the apple of the laser world, more expensive than a better option and a closed ecosystem .... 

Not for me but others might enjoy it.
video: Should You Buy a Glowforge?

text: After running a Glowforge pro for a couple hundred hours and while it is a great unit, I have several problems with it. the online software can be a bit finicky. I've had some of the ribbon cables go bad and I wouldn't have made the lid work off a ribbon cable as well. When the lid cable went bad, the unit was useless which IMO is unacceptable. I don't need a camera to run a laser.

text: Fiber lasers don't use "a bunch of diodes".  In a fiber laser, the laser light is created inside of a specially "doped" fiber.  It's the fiber that provides the light amplification and "pumps" the light.

text: The fiber laser is unique in that the fibet itself is whar creates the laser light  or more specificly the excited ions doped within the lattice of the crystal or glass fiber. Most of the time or at least for consumer focused fiber lasers they are pumped with a powerful    bank  of LEDs which is the excitation source stimulating the emission of radiation. These types of lasers can be significantly less expensive for maintenance as well as initial cost thanks to the more simple beam path. Obviously there are many other factors involved in the cost of the unit and  quality of the beam,  spectrum of the beam , how the beams pulse shape  and duration are controlled ,  or if it has a continuous wave stable  beam... sorry,  i love lasers haha

text:
No cable chain on X axis NEJE are making this look not good I have the
 ortur M2 nothing but problems glasses that come with this ones and the older one are dangerous 
If I was buying again NEJE 
THE Z lift should come with it good video but not really any difference to the old one 40w for cutting NEJE DUEL laser also no air to cool cut also the cover will block all the smoke and make it dirty better steppers on this one 400x430 on old one less on this one. over priced front broad is off a 3d printer you will incounter USB DISCONNECTED half way though your work fan on top of the laser cheap and bearing spline goes off centre and catches outer case earthing problems and static build up you have to add extra grounding wires and even to the earth pole outside no joke the pcb.s are not coated or sealed off so your dust plastic wood just goes right in there you buy it you should be able to plug it in after assemble and work but within an hour your modding adding things just to get it to work
I'd never buy another one 
And if your in the UK like me ¬£80 $100 import fee
This one does not look much better than the M2 
I think the product need more thought.. power supply cable chains better molex connectors to steppers and laser air feed nozzle and pipes free Z axis when you buy 
Sorry to go on but people need to know these are the few problems with the M2 and most likely this one to 
If your cutting co2 if it's tiles etc 20w or neje duel 40w with adjustable lense anyway good luck enjoy all

text: There is one very important test you either did not do or did and it would have ruined the review and that is durability testing! Probably the single most important test and one most people are going to be wanting to know more than anything (even if it never crossed their mind)! So how about it, how about REALLY putting it to the test and let us know how long we can expect it to survive before it burns out? The biggest issue with these diode lasers is they are weak and have such dismal life expectancies if that was known before the purchase people would not waste their money and it bothers me that someone like you that works with all types of lasers all the time, at least thats what you claim, one would think you are aware of this major issue! Yet its the one thing you make ZERO mention of and I just have to ask, is that because you already know it sucks?
